results.title: Movies Survived 2020. The Oscars Diversified. There’s More to Do.
results.abstract: At the pandemic Oscars, anything could happen. Here are the lessons from the nominations: The good, the bad and what needs fixing.

results.title: Red Carpet or Not, Film Festivals Roll On
results.abstract: Fresh leadership and veteran instincts helped keep film festivals running during the pandemic. The leaders of the major festivals speak about how.
des_facet: South by Southwest Music and Media Conference

results.title: Every Film in This Oscar Category Is an Underdog You Can Root for
results.abstract: Live-action shorts were once as mainstream as best picture. Now they’re treated as afterthoughts. Their history reflects the evolution of Hollywood.

results.title: ‘Nomadland’ Wins Big at Diverse BAFTAs
results.abstract: Four awards went to Chloé Zhao’s tale of itinerant Americans, living in vans and rolling through gorgeous landscapes, seeking temporary jobs to eke out an existence.

results.title: Will People of Color Win All Four Acting Oscars This Year?
results.abstract: Plenty of Academy Awards history could be made at this year’s ceremony, especially if the SAG Award winners repeat. Here are some records that could fall.

multimedia.caption: Clockwise from top left, Daniel Kaluuya in “Judas and the Black Messiah”; Chadwick Boseman in “Ma Rainey's Black Bottom”; Yuh-Jung Youn in “Minari”; and Viola Davis in “Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.” All four were winners at the SAG Awards and could repeat at the Academy Awards.

results.title: With a New Museum, African Workers Take Control of Their Destiny
results.abstract: A Dutch artist worked with former plantation employees to create a “white cube” that they hope will one day display works returned from European museums.

results.title: Benita Raphan, Maker of Lyrical Short Films, Is Dead at 58
results.abstract: Her dreamlike “genius” films about figures like Emily Dickinson and Buckminster Fuller hovered between documentary and experimental cinema.

multimedia.caption: The filmmaker Benita Raphan in her New York City apartment in 1999. She was a gleaner, a friend said — an urban anthropologist who found unusual objects that often ended up in her films.
multimedia.copyright: Barbara Alper for The New York Times

results.title: Chloé Zhao Becomes Second Woman to Win Top Directors Guild Award
results.abstract: The “Nomadland” filmmaker is  the first woman of color to take the feature-film directing prize. She’s now the prohibitive front-runner for the Oscar.

results.title: A Soviet ‘Lord of the Rings’ Is Unearthed, Epic in Its Own Way
results.abstract: Tolkien fans received an unexpected gift with the rediscovery of an all-but-forgotten 1991 production. They were also left with questions, like “why is Gollum wearing a lettuce on his head?”

results.title: Overlooked No More: Granville Redmond, Painter, Actor, Friend
results.abstract: He was known for his California landscapes. Deaf since childhood, he acted with Charlie Chaplin in silent films, an early example of deaf representation in Hollywood.

multimedia.caption: The painter and actor Granville Redmond conversing with the film star Charlie Chaplin around 1918. Redmond acted in seven Chaplin movies and the two became friends.
